sen.j: 安祥寺（あんしょうじ）は京都市山科区にある高野山真言宗の仏教寺院。
sen.e: Ansho-ji Temple (Kyoto City) is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Kyoyasan Shingon Sect located in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City.
Ansho-ji Temple (Kyoto City) is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Kyoyasan Shingon Sect located in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City.
Ansho-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Koyasan Shingon Sect located in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 山号は吉祥山、本尊は十一面観音、開山は恵運。
sen.e: The temple's honorific mountain prefix is Kisshozan, its principal image is the Eleven-faced Kannon and it was founded by Keiun.
The temple's honorific mountain prefix is Kisshozan, its principal image is the Eleven-faced Kannon and it was founded by Keiun.

The temple's sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Kisshozan, its principal image is the Eleven-faced Kannon and it was founded by Keiun.

sen.j: 朝廷縁の定額寺の一つ。
sen.e: It was one of the Jogaku-ji (government-subsidized temples) with a relationship to the Imperial Court.
It was one of the Jogaku-ji (government-subsidized temples) with a relationship to the Imperial Court.
It was one of the Jogaku-ji (government-subsidized temples) with a relationship to the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 沿革
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 嘉祥元年（848年）、仁明天皇女御で文徳天皇の母・藤原順子の発願により、入唐僧・恵運によって創建された。
sen.e: Ansho-ji Temple was founded by Keiun in the year 848 following a vow made by FUJIWARA no Nobuko, the concubine of Emperor Ninmei and the mother of Emperor Buntoku.
Ansho-ji Temple was founded by Keiun in the year 848 following a vow made by FUJIWARA no Nobuko, the concubine of Emperor Ninmei and the mother of Emperor Buntoku.

Ansho-ji Temple was founded by a nyuto-priest (priest wet to China for studying), Keiun, in the year 848 following a vow made by FUJIWARA no Nobuko, the concubine of the Emperor Ninmei and the mother of Emperor Buntoku.
sen.cmt: a nyuto-priest (prest wet to China for studying)補足"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 天皇の母に関係した寺であることから斉衡2年(855年)に定額寺となる。
sen.e: Due to its connection to the mother of the emperor, the temple was made a Jogaku-ji (government-subsidized temple) in the year 855.
Due to its connection to the mother of the emperor, the temple was made a Jogaku-ji (government-subsidized temple) in the year 855.
Due to its connection to the mother of the emperor, the temple was made a Jogaku-ji (government-subsidized temple) in the year 855.

sen.j: 『延喜式』によると順子の陵は山科にあるとされ、この寺との深い関係がうかがえる。
sen.e: According to "Engishiki" (laws and regulations of the Engi era), the tomb of FUJIWARA no Nobuko is in Yamashina and is thought to have a deep connection to the temple.
According to "Engishiki" (laws and regulations of the Engi era), the tomb of FUJIWARA no Nobuko is in Yamashina and is thought to have a deep connection to the temple.
According to "Engishiki" (laws and regulations of the Engi era), the tomb of Nobuko is in Yamashina and is thought to have a deep connection to the temple.

sen.j: 安祥寺には醍醐寺同様、裏の山にある「上寺」と麓にある「下寺」が存在した。
sen.e: As is the case for Daigo-ji Temple, Ansho-ji Temple had both a "Kami-dera" (upper temple) on the mountain to its rear and a "Shimo-dera" (lower temple) at the foot of the mountain.
As is the case for Daigo-ji Temple, Ansho-ji Temple had both a "Kami-dera" (upper temple) on the mountain to its rear and a "Shimo-dera" (lower temple) at the foot of the mountain.
As is the case for Daigo-ji Temple, Ansho-ji Temple had both a 'Kami-dera' (upper temple) on the mountain to its rear and a 'Shimo-dera' (lower temple) at the foot of the mountain.

sen.j: この2寺の詳細な成立時期はよく分かっていない。
sen.e: The precise time at which these two temples were established is not known.
The precise time at which these two temples were established is not known.
The precise time at which these two temples were established is not known.

sen.j: 先に僧侶の修行場としてすでに「上寺」があり、その後恵運に帰依した順子によって下寺が建立されたという説が有力である。
sen.e: The most likely theory is that "Kami-dera" first existed as a place of ascetic practice for monks, following which the "Shimo-dera" was founded by FUJIWARA no Nobuko who had become devoted to Keiun.
The most likely theory is that "Kami-dera" first existed as a place of ascetic practice for monks, following which the "Shimo-dera" was founded by FUJIWARA no Nobuko who had become devoted to Keiun.
The most likely theory is that 'Kami-dera' first existed as a place of ascetic practice for monks, following which the Shimo-dera was founded by FUJIWARA no Nobuko who had become devoted to Keiun.

sen.j: 恵運が貞観_(日本)9年(867年）に作成した「安祥寺伽藍縁起資財帳」（現在東寺蔵）によると、上寺には礼仏堂と五大堂とから成る堂院・東西僧房・庫裏・浴堂などの施設が、下寺には約2万平方メートルの寺域内に塔・仏堂・僧坊・門楼などがあったとされる。
sen.e: According to "Ansho-ji Garan Engi Shizai-cho" (records of materials used in the construction of Ansho-ji Temple) (currently in the possession of To-ji Temple) written by Keiun in the year 867, the Kami-dera included a main hall consisting of a Reibutsu-do (prayer hall) and a Godai-do (hall dedicated to the five guardian kings), eastern and western monks' living quarters, a kuri (food preparation building) and a bathing hall while the Shimo-dera was a site of approximately 20,000 square meters including a pagoda, a Buddha statue hall, monks' living quarters and a gate tower.

According to "Ansho-ji Garan Engi Shizai-cho" (records of materials used in the construction of Ansho-ji Temple) (currently in the possession of To-ji Temple) written by Keiun in the year 867, the Kami-dera included a main hall consisting of a Reibutsu-do (prayer hall) and a Godai-do (hall dedicated to the five guardian kings), eastern and western monks' living quarters, a kuri (food preparation building) and a bathing hall while the Shimo-dera was a site of approximately 20,000 square meters including a pagoda, a Buddha statue hall, monks' living quarters and a gate tower.

According to "Ansho-ji Garan Engi Shizai-cho" (records of materials used in the construction of Ansho-ji Temple) (currently in the possession of To-ji Temple) written by Keiun in the year 867, the Kami-dera included a main hall consisting of a Reibutsu-do (prayer hall) and a Godai-do (hall dedicated to the five guardian kings), eastern and western monks' living quarters, a kuri (food preparation building) and a bathing hall while the Shimo-dera was a site of approximately 20,000 square meters including a pagoda, a Buddha statue hall, monks' living quarters and a gate tower.

sen.j: しかし、順子が死去したあとは朝廷の庇護を失い次第に衰微していったようで、『小右記』ではすでに上寺に行く道が非常に荒れていることが記述されている。
sen.e: However, the temple gradually went into decline after losing the patronage of the Imperial Court following the death of FUJIWARA no Nobuko, "Shoyu-ki" (the diary of FUJIWARA no Sanesuke) describes how that the path leading to Kami-dera became extremely overgrown.

However, the temple gradually went into decline after losing the patronage of the Imperial Court following the death of FUJIWARA no Nobuko, "Shoyu-ki" (the diary of FUJIWARA no Sanesuke) describes how that the path leading to Kami-dera became extremely overgrown.

However, the temple gradually went into decline after losing the patronage of the Imperial Court following the death of Nobuko, "Shoyu-ki" (the diary of FUJIWARA no Sanesuke) describes how that the path leading to Kami-dera became extremely overgrown.

sen.j: 平安時代後期にこの寺に入った宗意は下寺の復興をはかる。
sen.e: In the latter part of the Heian period, a monk named Soi attempted to restore Shimo-dera,
In the latter part of the Heian period, a monk named Soi attempted to restore Shimo-dera,
In the latter part of the Heian period, a monk named Soi attempted to restore Shimo-dera.

sen.j: その後、上寺の方は延文年間まではかろうじて存続していたようだが、他の京都の多くの寺同様応仁の乱により、上寺・下寺共に完全に廃寺となる。
sen.e: Following this, Kami-dera barely managed to continue until the Enbun era (1356-1360) but both Kami-dera and Shimo-dera, as with many other temples in Kyoto, were completely abandoned due to the Onin War.

Following this, Kami-dera barely managed to continue until the Enbun era (1356-1360) but both Kami-dera and Shimo-dera, as with many other temples in Kyoto, were completely abandoned due to the Onin War.

Following this, Kami-dera barely managed to continue until the Enbun era (1356-1360) but both Kami-dera and Shimo-dera, as with many other temples in Kyoto, were completely abandoned due to the Onin War.

sen.j: 江戸時代に残った寺宝を元に現在地に移転して再建されるが、上寺の方は再建されず廃絶した。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the temple was reconstructed on its current site based on the remaining artifacts but Kami-dera was not rebuilt and disappeared.
In the Edo period, the temple was reconstructed on its current site based on the remaining artifacts but Kami-dera was not rebuilt and disappeared.
In the Edo period, the temple was reconstructed on its current site based on the remaining artifacts but Kami-dera was not rebuilt and disappeared.

sen.j: このときには高野山宝生院兼帯所となる。
sen.e: At this time it was under the joint administration of Koyasan Hosho-in Temple.
At this time it was under the joint administration of Koyasan Hosho-in Temple.
At this time it was under the joint administration of Koyasan Hosho-in Temple.

sen.j: さらに、寺領のほとんどを寺の維持のために毘沙門堂門跡に売却、寺の規模は大幅に縮小される。
sen.e: In addition, the size of the temple precinct was greatly reduced when the majority of the temple estate was sold to the Monzeki (priest prince) of Bishamon-do Temple in order to pay for maintenance.
In addition, the size of the temple precinct was greatly reduced when the majority of the temple estate was sold to the Monzeki (priest prince) of Bishamon-do Temple in order to pay for maintenance.
In addition, the size of the temple precinct was greatly reduced when the majority of the temple estate was sold to the Monzeki (priest prince) of Bishamon-do Temple in order to pay for maintenance.

sen.j: 江戸時代においても何回も火災に遭い、明治39年には多宝塔を焼失、以後再建されていない。
sen.e: The temple was damaged by fire on numerous occasions throughout the Edo period and the two-storey pagoda was not rebuilt after being completely destroyed by fire in 1906.
The temple was damaged by fire on numerous occasions throughout the Edo period and the two-storey pagoda was not rebuilt after being completely destroyed by fire in 1906.
The temple was damaged by fire on numerous occasions throughout the Edo period and the two-storey pagoda was not rebuilt after being completely destroyed by fire in 1906.

sen.j: 現在は江戸時代後期に再建された本堂、地蔵堂、大師堂のみが残る。
sen.e: All that remains now is the main hall, Jizo-do (hall dedicated to Jizo) and Daishi-do (hall dedicated to Kukai) that were all rebuilt during the latter part of the Edo period.
All that remains now is the main hall, Jizo-do (hall dedicated to Jizo) and Daishi-do (hall dedicated to Kukai) that were all rebuilt during the latter part of the Edo period.
All that remains now is the main hall, Jizo-do (hall dedicated to Jizo) and Daishi-do (hall dedicated to Kukai) that were all rebuilt during the latter part of the Edo period.

sen.j: 文化財
sen.e: Cultural Properties
Cultural Properties
Cultural properties

sen.j: 木造五智如来坐像（重要文化財） - 京都国立博物館に寄託。
sen.e: Wooden seated statues of the Five Wisdom Buddhas (Important Cultural Property): Deposited at Kyoto National Museum.
sen.cmt: 五智如来（大日・阿閃・宝生・阿弥陀・釈迦の5体）
sen.e: Wooden seated statues of the Five Wisdom Buddhas (Important Cultural Property): Deposited at Kyoto National Museum.
Wooden seated statues of the Five Wisdom Buddhas (Important Cultural Property): Deposited at Kyoto National Museum.

sen.j: 大日如来を中心とする金剛界の五仏で、安祥寺創建時の制作と推定される。
sen.e: The Five Buddhas of Vajradhatu (Diamond Realm) are centered around Dainichi Nyorai and estimated to have been crafted at the time of Ansho-ji Temple's founding.
The Five Buddhas of Vajradhatu (Diamond Realm) are centered around Dainichi Nyorai and estimated to have been crafted at the time of Ansho-ji Temple's founding.
The Five Buddhas of Vajradhatu (Diamond Realm) are centered around Dainichi Nyorai and estimated to have been crafted at the time of Ansho-ji Temple's founding.

sen.j: 明治39年（1906年）に焼けた多宝塔に安置されていたが、当時から京都国立博物館に寄託されていて難を逃れる。
sen.e: They were once housed within the two-storey pagoda that was destroyed by fire in 1906 but avoided damage as they had previously been deposited at Kyoto National Museum.
They were once housed within the two-storey pagoda that was destroyed by fire in 1906 but avoided damage as they had previously been deposited at Kyoto National Museum.
They were once housed within the two-storey pagoda that was destroyed by fire in 1906 but avoided damage as they had previously been deposited at Kyoto National Museum.

sen.j: 蟠龍石柱 - 唐時代。
sen.e: Coiled dragon stone pillar: Chinese Tang Dynasty.
Coiled dragon stone pillar: Chinese Tang Dynasty.
Coiled dragon stone pillar: Chinese Tang Dynasty.

sen.j: 京都国立博物館に寄託。
sen.e: Deposited at Kyoto National Museum.
Deposited at Kyoto National Museum.
Deposited at Kyoto National Museum.

sen.j: なお、東寺観智院にある五大虚空蔵菩薩像（唐時代、重要文化財）はもと安祥寺にあったもので、恵運が唐から将来した仏像である。
sen.e: The statues of the Five Great Akasagarbha at Kanchi-in Temple in To-ji Temple (Chinese Tang Dynasty, Important Cultural Properties) were brought to Japan from Tang Dynasty China by Keiun and were originally kept at Ansho-ji Temple.

The statues of the Five Great Akasagarbha at Kanchi-in Temple in To-ji Temple (Chinese Tang Dynasty, Important Cultural Properties) were brought to Japan from Tang Dynasty China by Keiun and were originally kept at Ansho-ji Temple.

sen.j: 京都市山科区御陵平林町22
sen.e: 22 Goryo Hirabayashi-Cho, Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City

sen.j: 西日本旅客鉄道・京阪電気鉄道線山科駅から徒歩10分。
sen.e: 10 minutes walk from JR West/Keihan Electric Railways Yamashina Station.
10 minutes walk from JR West/Keihan Electric Railways Yamashina Station.

sen.j: ただし、非公開寺院で境内に立ち入ることはできない。
sen.e: However the temple is not open to the public and the grounds cannot be entered.
However the temple is not open to the public and the grounds cannot be entered.

sen.j: 琵琶湖疎水に面しており、近辺は春は桜の名所である。
sen.e: The temple also faces the Lake Biwa Canal and the area is famous for its beautiful cherry blossoms.
